text:
I'm probably going to sit down
just because I have notes, and just to let
you know that I've

been working on this
project about women and interaction design
history for 2 and 1/2 years.

I finished my
manuscript in December, so I have not internalized
everything yet. I don't have
everything memorized,

but I wanted to bring some of
the stories to you guys today.

So I think it's important
to talk about our history and in looking back
at our history,

it helps us think about what
we're going to do in the future. And next week is Women's
History Month starts,

so it's a perfect
time to do this. So let me set some
context first.

Against the growing
disillusionment of post-war 1950s
perfect housewife-era,

we see in the '60s,
we start to see second wave feminism
and more and more women

starting to move
into the workforce. This started in the
'60s and ran for about--

second wave feminism
ran for about 20 years. And women were concerned
with equal equality,

with pay equality,
financial independence, and bodily autonomy. And we see the first
group of women starting

to move into the workforce
in large, large waves because they start to be allowed
to be independent earners.

Up until this point,
they had part-time jobs. They weren't allowed to have
their own bank accounts.

They weren't allowed
to have credit cards. And then the availability
of birth control facilitated this
because people could

start to plan their families
and they could delay marriage. And so that's important
to set the background.

So these are just a few dates
of things starting to change,

when many of the
ivy league schools started to allow women
into their classes

and into the degree programs,
not in the sister schools. So this wasn't that long ago.

In contrast, Stanford
actually allowed women. It was co-educational
from the beginning

and offered advanced degrees
to women, starting in 1891. So very progressive.
[INAUDIBLE] Pardon?

So despite these
dissolving barriers, women were entering
tech companies,

they were joining
the research labs, and they were working
as consultants. And I've got a few of these
little diagrams, which,

hopefully, are readable. But some of the research
facilities and research labs

were Bell Labs, IBM's
Watson Lab, Xerox PARC,

Stanford Research institute. And there were also
consultants, and I'm going to talk about
one consultant first--

Stephanie Rosenbaum. Stephanie Rosenbaum began
her career in technology

as a consultant, and she founded
her company TecEd in 1967.

Her interest and
exposure in technology came when she participated
in a summer program

through the National
Science Foundation, and that specific
program she was a part of

was spearheaded by
anthropologist Margaret Mead in 1959. And they brought together
50 juniors from high school,

working with the computer
scientists and the big IBM 650, and teaching them for
transit in the summer.

And when I talked
with her, she talked about how exciting it was
and really interesting, but that programming was
not going to be for her.

So that's one of the
things she learned. But she realized that a
lot of the people involved in these programs were going
to start computer companies,

and they were terrible
communicators. So she saw her sweet spot,
and what she ended up doing

was studying language and
philosophy of language at UC Berkeley and getting
her master's and beginning

to write technical publications
and computer documentation, and then doing usability
and ease of use and ease

of understanding
on those documents. And that's how she
got into the field, and she is known as a
fore-mother of usability.

She founded her
company in Michigan because that's where
her husband was based. And so at this time,
many, many people

couldn't have their
own companies. They had to go where
their husbands went.

Their needs were second. This actually turned
out to be advantageous because she was in the
heartland and could

test with users that were
not in Silicon Valley. She kept an office
here, in Silicon Valley,

to be near the companies,
but her main office, with the usability
labs, are in Michigan.

Over the years, she got closer
and closer to actual software and less about
the documentation,

and by the time
the web came about, the company was designing
software as well as testing.

She got involved in
CHI early and with UPA, and began writing articles
and teaching ACI classes

and workshops before there
were a lot of programs. There were a few.

I think CMU existed. And she is still working now. 50 years later,
she's still working,

and last year, she got the UXPA
lifetime achievement award. And she's a hoot.

She's pretty funny. So 1974 is the first year
a woman could get a credit card on their own, without
their husband or their father

co-signing. It wasn't that long ago. So now I'm going to talk
about PARC, Xerox PARC.

You may have heard of a few
of these guys on this list, but there were also quite a
lot of women who held PhDs,

and they were working there. Many came in as interns
and postdocs to work,

including Marilyn
Tremain and Lucy Suchman, which you may have heard
of her, but I'm not going to talk about her today.

So I want to talk
about-- first, actually, I'm going to talk
about three women--

Adele Goldberg, Terry Roberts,
and Doris Wells-Papanek. And first, I'm going to
talk about Adele Goldberg.

And many people list her as
a programmer and a computer scientist, and they
would be totally right. But I am claiming her in the
early era of interaction design

because of much of the work
that she did-- straddled UX and design research. She got her PhD in
information sciences

at University of Chicago while
she was working as a research assistant here, at Stanford.

So there's a lot of people
I'm going to talk about that have association with Stanford.

And she got involved with
a special interest group with the ACM around education
and working with kids

and teaching them programming
and how to use computers. And Alan Kay from
PARC heard about her

and recruited her to come work
at PARC with him, in 1972.

And they worked on the
Dynabook together, which was one of his inventions,
and on Smalltalk, which he had created.

And she was instrumental in
designing the user research with kids to test on
the Alto and the Star.

And one of the things
they were doing was teaching the students about
object-oriented programming

and how to use that to
create other programs, and then testing that
process and iterating.

She was part of the
team that actually did the demo of Smalltalk
to the Apple folks.

And many of you may
have heard that story, that Steve jobs and the Apple
people came in, they saw it,
they stole the ideas. That's actually not true. They didn't steal the ideas.

Xerox was a funder. They were one of the investors
in Apple, and part of that trade

was to get a demo of
Smalltalk and the Star system. And she was part of that
and did not want to do it.

She knew that those
guys would totally understand how things work
and would take it and run, and she resisted, and the
corporate folks in New York

basically told her
she had to do it. So they ordered her to
do it, and she was right.

The Apple folks understood
how things worked, and it heavily
influenced the Macintosh.

They were already
starting that work, but it changed a lot of things.

And of course, the
Mac, we all know Macs. Nobody really knows
about the Xerox Star.

But one of the things
that she also did was work on the
Smalltalk 76, which led to the work on Smalltalk 80.

And when Alan Kay
left to go to Atari, she took over managing
the team and was

responsible for writing a series
of books about Smalltalk 80, including the book on
interface and user interface.

And that was a collection of
the components and how they work and how you would use them
together, and defining that.

And this documentation is one
of the earliest documentation of user interface, way
before the Human Interface

Guidelines come out from Apple. And Smalltalk was an
object-oriented language.

It influenced the
Gang of Four, who wrote the book Design Patterns,
which influenced Jennifer Tidwell, who pulled together
her set of interaction design

patterns in designing
interfaces, which then influenced the work that
I did at Yahoo, and then

a whole slew of interaction
design pattern libraries around there. So this is sort of the early
proto foundation of that.

But it also was the first
overlapping windows interface.

It was one of the first
object-oriented programming languages. It was the first
application delivery system.

There were a lot
of firsts with this that hadn't been seen before. Integrated multimedia
and video conferencing

were all part of
the system that she was driving, having worked
on that with Alan Kay.

So 1978 is the first year
a woman's job was protected if they became pregnant.

Up until that point, if
a woman got pregnant, she could be fired.

And then the Pregnancy
Discrimination Act was passed, which
made discrimination

by being pregnant part of the
sexual discrimination laws. So the next person I want to
talk about is Terry Roberts,

and she came to
California to get her PhD.

She was looking at Stanford. And she wasn't sure where she
also wanted to do her research, so she looked at PARC and she
looked at Stanford Research

Institute, and she ended up
becoming interested in PARC after Stuart Card and Tom
Moran from Carnegie Mellon

created their HCI Research Lab,
the research group at PARC. And so she worked with them.

She actually was the first
PhD in HCI, here at Stanford, before that degree existed, and
she got that degree in like '78.

She worked on her
PhD '77 to '78. It still doesn't exist. What? It still doesn't exist. Oh, it still doesn't exist?

Not a degree. OK, well, she got the first one. For something that
doesn't exist, there are quite a lot
of people who have it.

So she also worked on
the Star, so you're going to see the Star
a couple more times. And it was a work in progress
when she started, so she ended

up doing a lot of usability
testing of components, and on the parts and the
pieces of interaction.

And one of the things
I found interesting when I spoke with her
about that was she

talked about how it
actually didn't succeed and the reasons why. In addition to the hardware
being super, super expensive,

the Star was a closed system. So everything happened
within a document. The spreadsheets were
inside the document,

the image editing was
inside a document, and that meant that
other developers couldn't come in and build software
to run on the hardware,

unlike the Macintosh, which
was an open system, where outside people could
create software.

So in her mind,
that was probably

another reason why it failed. And she was there until '87 when
she went to US West, in Boulder.

And US West was one
of the Baby Bells. In the '80s, the Bell
Corporation was broken up

into a whole bunch of smaller
Bell systems because of--

what's the-- Anti-monopoly. Yes, thank you, anti-monopoly. And when she went to
Bell, she actually

was part of the standards
group across the Baby Bells working on phone prompt systems.

And they developed
the semantic structure "To reach X, press N," which I'm
sure you've heard when you've

gotten into a phone
tree, and that became an adopted pattern for
almost every phone tree system

going forward. So I found that
pretty interesting, that as an interaction designer
and researcher, you were also--

We don't hear a lot about
voice UX early on, that early. She also worked at a
variety of other companies

over her career-- Peoplesoft, Intuit. She was the single
designer and researcher

on Quickbooks for accountants. And then she finished out
her career at Tableau, working on data cleaning tools.

And when I spoke with her, she
just lit up, talking about data and working with data and
creating tools for data.

But she retired in 2019,
and information about her is really hard to find.

And one of the reasons why I
started working on this project is because people are retiring
and their work is disappearing,

and if we don't
write it down, nobody will know they even existed. So we don't want that to happen.

So 1980 was the year the Equal
Employment Opportunity declared that sexual
harassment on the job

was a form of sexual
discrimination. So I thought that was
interesting, since that was not

that long ago. But even by the 1980s,
there were still

companies in universities where
if a woman was offered a job and her husband worked
there, she couldn't take it.

They had to work in
some place different. So many women were
locked out of places

to work because of where
their husbands worked. And I saw that story over and
over in many of the interviews

that I did. Yes? Does it go both ways,
where the husband was offered a job where a woman
worked, he also didn't take it?

Yes, technically. But more than
likely, they probably would have asked the woman to
leave just because of the way

women were
discriminated against. But yeah, in these
companies, married couples

could not work in
the same company. So he probably wouldn't
have been offered a job,

or if it was a different
job or a higher job, she probably would have
been asked to leave. I don't know that
for a fact, though.

But good question. So the next person I'd like to
talk about, just very quickly,

is Doris Wells-Papanek. She trained at Kansas City Art
Institute with Victor Papanek.

She studied with him. Her last name comes from
marrying a distant cousin that she met way after
she studied with him,

so it was not like he introduced
her to his son or something. She started at PARC
in '83, the same year

that Susan Kerr
started at Apple, working on the icon and font
designs on the Macintosh.

She came to California
and was working and researched and
asking her network where should she work, where's
the best place to work,

and they said PARC. So she actually ended up
getting hired at PARC, and she was the first
formally trained designer

working at PARC. She was not a PhD. And she also worked
on the Star system.

So at this point, everybody
worked on the Star system. And these are not the most
sexy icons, but you know,

we're talking '83. She primarily worked on
icons with another designer named Norm Cox.

And when she started, only the
PhDs could touch the computers. So that makes it really
hard to do your work,

if you can't actually
do your work. But she ended up proving herself
by working with the development

teams down in El Segundo,
which was a group that had been acquired by PARC
and all the developers

were down there. And so she went down there
and worked with them, and that success
created trust up here,

in Palo Alto, where PARC is. And she also brought in
this sort of ethos of design

into the group, where she would
post things in the hallways and design in public and people
could see what she was doing,

and that kind of
changed the atmosphere. She left-- Oh, did you-- Did you get this image from her?

Because the inbox
is clearly hers. No, actually. This, I got on Wikimedia. I mean, I tried to find--

The other pictures
of the Star, I got from Digibarn, which has
a whole collection of really

high-quality
polaroids of computers with the Star system on it,
and I got permission for that.

But this is up on the internet. But yeah, it's totally hers
because it says "Wells."

Yeah, and "Doris" is above that. Yeah. I was like, this is perfect. She left PARC in '89
and went to Apple

and joined the developer side
of Human Interface Group. And she also designed the
first internet browser

that was called
Cyberdog, which came out seven years before Safari.

And I don't have
a picture of that that I could find royalty-free,
but if you look up "cyberdog web

browser Apple," you'll see it. It was kind of like Netscape. It was all-encompassing, with
mail as well as news and web
browsing. And then she left PARC in '89-- or, I said that already.

She left Apple in '97
and moved to the Midwest

and went back to
school for education and has been using her
user-centered design skills

to work on designing and
developing new curriculum for K through 12, and then now
up into higher education.

So she uses her skills, but she
doesn't do work in tech anymore.

And she was an interesting
person that I talked to. So speaking of
Apple, so you guys may have heard of
some of these guys.

But there were a
whole lot of women in the Human Interface Group and
the Advanced Technology Group.

I'm kind of limiting my time
limit here from the early '80s

to '92, when Steve Jobs came
back and reworked everything and lots and lots
of people left.

So I'm going to talk
about three people here-- Kristina Hooper Woolsey, which
you guys may have heard of,

Joy Mountford, and Sue Booker,
which you may not have heard of.

So Kristina Hooper
Woolsey is considered the mother of
multimedia, which is

way before the days of the web. So once upon a time, we
experienced multimedia

on CD-ROMs, and it
was a hot-- that's what I thought I was going to do
when I got out of grad school,

do educational
CD-ROM multimedia. And by the time I got
out and started working,

the web came and it killed it. So that was a
short-lived goal of mine.

So Woolsey did her
post-doc work at MIT, and she spent '77 and '78
as a visiting professor

in the Architecture
Machine Group, working with
Nicholas Negroponte. And she worked on the
Aspen Movie project,

and you guys can look
that up on the web. It was a collaborative
team project

that photographed the
entire town of Aspen to create a multimedia
experience of being able to navigate and
fly through the town,

really like Google Earth today. So today, it's not
super impressive,

but in 1978, it was
pretty freaking amazing. According to her,
it was exhilarating,

full of great people, ideas,
and compelling projects. It was funded by the cybernetics
technology division of DARPA,

so government-funded. We see a few screens
from the laserdisc.

It was recorded to
laserdisc, and it is one of the first
multimedia titles ever.

The screen grabs that I got are
from a group called Domesday86,

and you can look that up. They have a video of the
whole video from the--

they have a badly damaged
copy of the laserdisc and they're trying
to restore it. But it's pretty
interesting to look at,

and there's some stills. There were different
levels of this. And then here's a
picture of a person

sort of sitting in front of the
projection of the laserdisc, and they could navigate left
and right through the town.

And this was
groundbreaking at the time. So after MIT, she came
back to California

and was the research
lab director at Atari, working with Alan
Kay and Brenda Laurel

until the company decided
to shut down the research lab because it
wasn't making money, because it's a research lab.

They wanted more of their
money going to making games, and so they shut the lab down
and they walked everyone out.

And that was in 1984. She ended up going
to Apple, and she worked with the Human
Interface Group,

doing the first early
definitions of UI elements, like dropdowns, how did windows
work, how did navigation work.

And this was right before
the Macintosh came out.
And then in 1986--

so at this point, Steve
Jobs is pushed out. He's gone. So she founded a
skunkworks group

with another woman
named Sueann Ambron, who was an education expert. They founded the
Multimedia Research Lab.

So during this heyday,
we have a whole lot of really interesting
titles coming out of Apple,

and their goal was to
explore multimedia, to explore animation, video,
sound, along with text

in the education space,
and how could they bring media to help change
how people were learning.

And for pretty much every
title that they delivered, she was the producer,
and then a designer

named Kristi Rosendahl was the
art director, who had come over from the Hypercard team.

And multimedia, they ended up
exploring all kinds of things,

and they also ended up
partnering with companies like Lucasfilms and
the Smithsonian,

and a lot of organizations
that were making content. So they were working on, how do
we bring these things together

in an interactive environment. Other people were
providing the content. And they started out
in black and white,

and eventually moved to color. Much more interactive as
Hypercard got more robust,

and then as Quicktime came
out, more video stuff.

So she was designated a
Distinguished Scientist in 1985-- probably one of
the few women at the time--

and after the multimedia
lab was shut down in '92, when Jobs came back, she
did continue at Apple until '97

and worked on a
variety of projects. When she left Apple, she
worked on this project

called VizAbility. Do you remember that? I have a couple of copies. Oh, OK. Well, basically, it was a
multimedia learning experience.

It was available
commercially, and it was designed to train people
how to see and how to draw, and it was co-created with the
designers Gail Curtis and Scott

Kemp. And the whole design system,
the visual design system, was developed by Metadesign.

And it was full of
videos and workbooks, and this was kind of at
the peak and the starting

the beginning of the waning of
multimedia, when this came out. Because I remember when it came
out, I was working on websites.

And as the multimedia
heyday waned, Woolsey moved on to work
with other projects,

and then eventually
at the Exploratorium, and led the efforts to
move the Exploratorium

from the Palace of Fine Arts
down to the fisherman's wharf. And she's done other
educational ventures.

And she recently self-published
a book about her time running the multimedia
research lab, so you can get it
on Amazon, which

I found really
interesting, and then I ended up exchanging
emails with her and getting a lot
more information.

So 1985, by this time, half
of all college graduates

were women. So we see this increase
of women coming into higher education, where
earlier, they were going

all the way up to getting PhDs. And by this time,
we have still many

going to get advanced
degrees, but also, we start to see people with
BFAs and MFAs starting

to work in some
of these companies because we're starting to
see some women as managers.

And we see a larger group
of relevant disciplines.

We start to see graphic
design being related, and the different psychology--
social psychology and cognitive

psychology, and we have
scholars from NYU and from MIT and from CMU coming to work in
these different organizations

and labs for their internships
and their research projects. So the last-- not the last
person, the second person

that I want to talk about
at Apple is Joy Mountford. And Joy Mountford was at Apple
starting in 1986, but prior

to that, she began her career
after grad school at Honeywell. And she was working on jet
cockpits, space shuttle

cockpits. She got her degree in
engineering psychology from the University
of Illinois, and she

was doing interaction
of screens and heads up display and VR stuff when
it was only available

in military situations. And she also had to think about
how did toilets work in space,

so there was a lot of
range of kinds of things that she was working on because
of the work at Honeywell.

And when I spoke with her-- and she's told the story before,
that when she interviewed

at Apple, she came home and she
cried because the screen was this big.

It was only in black and white. There was one keyboard
and one mouse. And if you look back,
look at all those screens,

look at all the
different controls-- 360 degrees, because
what's up in space, right?

And then this. But she obviously saw a promise
because she took the job,

but I just think it's
funny that she cried. So she came in to manage
the Human Interface Group.

And Christina Woolsey
told me about hiring her, and Mountford turned this
group from a team that

was documenting and evangelizing
UI components into a visionary inventive powerhouse in
and out of the company.

So she had a vision that
they were not just going to be the people who
documented how things worked for the programmers.

They were going to
do their own stuff. So one of the most well-known
inventions that came out of her

team-- and so this is
really, really tiny, because that's how tiny
Quicktime was when it first launched-- was Quicktime.

They were part of the team
that developed and invented Quicktime, Quicktime VR, a
whole host of Quicktime suites.

And that was not the
only one, the only thing. It's just one of
the most well-known. A more recent invention that
you can read about on Wikipedia

is called stacks-- or it was called "piles"
when it first came out. That just came out
three years ago.

It was invented back in
the '80s by this group. It was [INAUDIBLE].
Yeah. I don't have any pictures. [INAUDIBLE] Yeah.

There's all sorts of
stories like that, of things that the
group invented.

And so the group,
originally started by Bruce Tognazzini, and then
first versions of the Human

Interface Guidelines, he
led the efforts writing, but they were generally
published internally.

And when Joy came in, one of
the things she wanted to do was get this out because
people were starting to develop

software for the Mac system. And if you publish
those guidelines,

then people will
design to them and then you have an ecosystem
of software-- not just what
Apple was creating,

but what other
people were creating. And so that helped
raise and elevate the reputation of
this organization.

This other book, The Art of
Human Computer Interface Design was conceived by Joy,
edited by Brenda Laurel,

and it is full of essays written
by all the members of the group.

Many of them were
CHI papers first, that then are in the book,
along with some invited authors.

And it still holds up today. I think it was printed in
'91 or something like that. I have a copy.

And you read through it, and
it's like, this could be today. It is still evergreen. So many of the concepts
and ideas hold up.

So this partly helped
create this landscape

of respect and
ability for the group to be brought in as consultants.

When the company was
working with outside vendors and outside customers,
they helped show developers

how do you do design, how
do you test to make sure that your designs
and your interactions

are clear and understandable,
and how do you prototype. And so all the things they were
doing within the organization,

using tools like Hypercard
to build other tools, and using video and
storytelling, they were also

teaching to their customers and
people that they worked with, which just spread that
across Silicon Valley.

After the reorg at
Apple in '92, they changed the structure and
she and several others went to Interval Research.

One of the other things that
she worked on over time that she started at Apple was
this thing that she

called the Expo, where
it was essentially a sponsored studio that Apple
funded, where she would go

and partner with universities. But it wasn't just
one university. She would generally
have up to eight, and have a design prompt for
different groups of students

to be working against. And then they would bring
the winner out to Apple to present to the team and work
with the Apple folks, which

was pretty cool, and
they got some money, too. And so over the years, as she
moved from various companies,

working on ebooks and big
data and autonomous vehicles, she was able to get all
these other companies

to sponsor the Expo. And that lasted for 23 years. Unfortunately, the last two
companies she's worked at,

they don't do work
with students. So these pictures are from when
Yahoo sponsored the Expo back

when I was there and
when she was there. And you can see, in the black
and white picture, that's

Red Burns from NYU
talking to Don Norman. And it was crazy stuff. So the middle one are these
little babies and lollipops,

that as you lick, the
babies would move, and the faster you licked,
the faster they moved. I mean, it was
just totally weird.

It was really weird. But it was experimental
and exploratory, and who knows what
would happen with that?

And I don't know if you
have a group of people doing that, you don't want a second
group of people coming up

after them. Anyway, it was a little weird. But the Expo in and
of itself allowed

Joy to work with thousands of
students over these 23 years, across the world, and to
mentor and sort of spread

the word about good design. So the last person from Apple
that I want to talk about is Sue Booker.

And so Sue graduated in the mid
'80s from University of Michigan

with a degree in
industrial design. But she actually started
her job, her first job,

as an interaction
designer because she'd done her resume on
a Mac and had played

around doing some Mac screens. And so she ended up being
an interaction designer

for the bulk of her career. She was hired
right out of school by Bill Moggridge at ID2--

before it was IDO-- and she was the first
interaction designer hired into the firm.

She also was the only
one not from Stanford, and the only one not British.

So there was a lot of
firsts for her, there. And she was the only female
designer in the firm,

for a while. And one of their
clients was PARC, and so she got to spend a
whole lot of time at PARC,

and ended up working
with Bill Verplank and collaborating
with him, and then they poached him over into ID2.

But she got to work on things
like interactive whiteboards and sort of crazy stuff that
